text: - Welcome to Lugano.
(lively music)

- Known as the Mediterranean
of Switzerland,

Ticino is an enchanting lake
district bordering Italy,

where colorful buildings
line waterfront promenades

housing palm trees, outdoor
cafes, and warm breezes.

Medieval castles are
scattered throughout a land
of lakes and valleys with emerald waters.
And Italian pastas and seafood
trump cheese fondue and raclette.

Are you ready to explore the
Italian Riviera of Switzerland?
Let's all go to Ticino.
(bright music)

We have arrived in the
beautiful Canton of Ticino,
which is the Italian part of Switzerland.

It has a completely different
feel from the mountains.
I do actually feel like I'm in Italy.

There's cappuccinos, there's
cheese, there's pasta,
and there's beautiful lakes and scenery.

The first stop on our Ticino
tour was the Verzasca Valley.

It's famous for its
glowing emerald waters,

flowing fast through the
smooth boulders of the valley
and its historic bridges.
A top draw is swimming and jumping off
the Ponte dei Salti stone arched bridge.

This town is so picturesque,
and it's great to go for a hike
or spend a day just basking in the sun.

- Entertaining, just
watching them jump off there.
Not for me, thanks.

- [Deb] Crazy.
- Not for me, thanks.

No thanks.

- The crystal clear waters
attract scuba divers
and locals and tourists alike,
to relax on the smooth rocks
and take a dip in the clear waters.
But be warned, the water is cold
and it moves very fast in some places.

It's pretty cool to just be
hiking these ancient footpaths
that have been used for centuries.

And the scenery around
here is just beautiful.

So if you wanna go for a

it's just 15 minutes up to the next town.

And you go through the old

that have been used in

Feels like nothing has changed.

- So cool, hiking these ancient trails.
- Lavertezzo is a picturesque town
that is a really great visit,

to go for a swim, or
watch the cliff jumpers,

or just sit by the
water and have a coffee.
(soft music)
(bright lively music)
Well, I think we must be doing

because I see these
signs everywhere we go.
This one's in Ascona.

Ascona is a beautiful
town on Lake Maggiore.

I would say it's Switzerland's
answer maybe to Lake Como.

You know, you just wanna
walk around the old town,
have a drink on the promenade,

or just stroll the really
pretty pastel buildings.
Or do what Dave's doing. Dance.

Ascona was our favorite
town to visit in Ticino.

It is truly beautiful, with
cafes lining the waterfront.
The pedestrian village doesn't allow cars,
and you can walk the streets
perusing the galleries and boutiques

without having to worry
about any vehicles.

Make sure to stroll along
the tree-lined waterfront
at Piazza Giuseppe Motta,

and pull a seat up at
one of the many cafes.

You can even take a boat
ride on Lake Maggiore
to cross into Italy.
- A good way to explore Ascona here,
just jump on the little trolley behind me,
and it takes you all around,
gives you a little tour of the city.
- At Ascona's waterfront is also
one of the Swings of the World.
There are 12 of them around Ticino.
(lively music)

I don't know if anyone else
has ever said this before,

but I really feel that Lugano
reminds me of Rio de Janeiro.

It has this waterfront path
with these grand buildings,

and then you have these high
mountains on either side of it,
framing it.
It's just a beautiful place
to go for a stroll on the promenade,

to have a coffee or aperitivo,
and relax for the afternoon.
(energetic music)
Nestled between Lake Como in Italy
and Lake Maggiore in Switzerland,
Lake Lugano has top billing
as one of the best things to do in Ticino.

It will in fact remind
you of Rio de Janeiro,

with Monte San Salvatore and
Monte Br√® framing the city,
just like the South American country.
Strolling along the waterfront is a must,
and make sure to keep an eye out
for all of the art installations
that line the two-kilometer route
from Paradiso to Parco Ciani.

There's also a beach and
marina with beautiful scenery,

where you can dip your
toes in Lake Lugano.
(gentle music)

One of the most popular
ways to enjoy Lake Lugano
is to get out on a paddle boat.
They have a lot of unique ones here,

with slides, there's
party boats, there's cars.
It's a good way to explore.

Get on the water and see the
city from a different view.

One of the top places to visit in Ticino
is the Verzasca Dam.

It's famous for the James
Bond film "GoldenEye,"
where he bungee-jumped off of the dam.
So you can come here and recreate it,
'cause they actually do bungee jumping.

So to visit the dam, all you
have to do is pay for parking,

and then you can just walk
out for free and check it out,
and see this super-high dam in the valley,
which is extraordinary.
It is crazy high.
So parking costs two Swiss francs,

and it's a pretty cheap
attraction to check out.
The Verzasca Dam is 220 meters high,

and you can book bungee
jumps from the top.

It's located en route
to the Verzasca Valley,

so you can stop on your way
there, or on your way back.
But parking is limited,

so if you see a spot when
you're going by, take it.

Well, this is the highest
bungee jump in Europe,
at 220 meters.
So if you want a thrill, come on down here

in Ticino, to do it.

You have to reserve online,
there's certain hours,

On your way up to the dam
there's a great pull-off,

So just look for it when

We have come off the
world's steepest funicular

here in Ticino, and it has
gorgeous views of the valley.
There's some great hikes you can do.

So if you do come up here,
bring all your hiking gear

and you can hike out for
about two and a half hours
to a little hut,

where you can have some
lunch, and then hike on back.
The Ritom funicular was built in 1921

and the 15-minute journey
will take you up 1787 meters,

where you can hike to the
Ritom dam and Lake Cadagno.

It offers beautiful views
of the Piora Valley.
Make sure to take some water with you.
And if you don't have snacks,

you can hike right out to
Capanna Cadagno for some lunch.
Well, we made it to the lake.

This is the highest and biggest

but unfortunately we have

So we're not gonna make it.
But if you do come out here,

- Come to the Castles of Bellinzona.
(lively music)
- Bellinzona is the capital
of the Ticino region of Switzerland,

and is not to be missed
for its three castles

that are a designated
UNESCO World Heritage site.

Castelgrande, Montebello,
and Sasso Corbaro,
plus the castle walls of Bellinzona

have all been restored,
and are open to tourists.
You can hike to each one of them,
with Castelgrande being located
right downtown in Bellinzona.

The Grand Piazza is one
of the biggest piazzas
in Switzerland,
and it's known for its many festivals.

And one that's going on
now, or about to go on,
is the Locarno Film Festival.
Located on Lake Maggiore,
Locarno is another lovely town in Ticino,

with pastel buildings
lining its waterfront.
Get lost in its cobblestone streets,
or sip espresso in Piazza Grande,
Switzerland's largest square.

While in Locarno, you can hike
up to the Madonna del Sasso,

or take the funicular up
to this 14th-century church
that is a popular pilgrimage site.

Well, on our way to Ticino,
we have just crossed

the highest mountain pass in
Switzerland with a paved road.
And it's a fun drive.
There's a ton of switchbacks.

There's sports cars and
motorcycles just whizzing by us.
It's too much fun.

We've arrived in Ticino at

This is swanky, man.

I doubt we'll be watching.

Now come on down and see.

Our European standards.
So this is it. This is our room.
The resort is a beautiful retreat

located on 25 hectares
of vineyards, parklands,

with a scenic pool
overlooking Lake Lugano.

After spending some
time in the Swiss Alps,
this is a little slice of heaven,

in the spa and sauna.
